facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 48 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 48 of 1954. Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 1 1 th January, 1954, of the High Court of Judicature of Mysore in Civil Petition No. 29 of 1953, quashing the Order of the Election Tribunal, Shimoga, dated the 15th January, 1953, in Shimoga No. I of 1952-53.

facts.text: Mysore High Court delivered judgment and order dated 11th January 1954 in Civil Petition No. 29 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 1 1 th January, 1954, of the High Court of Judicature of Mysore in Civil Petition No. 29 of 1953, quashing the Order of the Election Tribunal, Shimoga, dated the 15th January, 1953, in Shimoga No. I of 1952-53. S. Krishnaswami Iyengar  K. S. Venkataranga Iyengar and M. S. K. Iyengar, with him  for the appellant.

facts.text: Election Tribunal Shimoga delivered order dated 15th January 1953 in Shimoga Election Case No. 1 of 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: quashing the Order of the Election Tribunal, Shimoga, dated the 15th January, 1953, in Shimoga No. I of 1952-53. S. Krishnaswami Iyengar  K. S. Venkataranga Iyengar and M. S. K. Iyengar, with him  for the appellant. Dr. Bakshi Tek Chand  R. Ganapathy Iyer and M. S. K. Sastri, with him  for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: General election held in January 1952 for Mysore Legislative Assembly from Tarikere Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: were duly nominated candidates for election to the Mysore Legislative Assembly from Tarikere Constituency at the general election of that State held in January , 1952. Five of these nominated candidates withdrew their candidature within the prescribed period and the actual contest at the election was between the remaining five candidates including the appellant and respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Polling took place on 4th January 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The polling took place on the 4th January, 1952, and the votes were counted on the 26th of January following. As a result, of the counting the respondent No. 1 was found to have secured 8,093 votes which was the largest in number and the appellant followed him closely having obtained 8,059 votes.

facts.text: Votes were counted on 26th January 1952.

anchor.surface_text: 1952, and the votes were counted on the 26th of January following. As a result, of the counting the respondent No. 1 was found to have secured 8,093 votes which was the largest in number and the appellant followed him closely having obtained 8,059 votes. The remaining three candidates, who were respondents Nos. 2, 3 and 4 before the High Court, got respectively 6,239, 1,644 and 1,142 votes.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 secured 8,093 votes.

anchor.surface_text: the counting the respondent No. 1 was found to have secured 8,093 votes which was the largest in number and the appellant followed him closely having obtained 8,059 votes. The remaining three candidates, who were respondents Nos. 2, 3 and 4 before the High Court, got respectively 6,239, 1,644 and 1,142 votes. The Returning Officer declared the respondent No. 1 to be the successful candidate

facts.text: Appellant obtained 8,059 votes.

anchor.surface_text: the largest in number and the appellant followed him closely having obtained 8,059 votes. The remaining three candidates, who were respondents Nos. 2, 3 and 4 before the High Court, got respectively 6,239, 1,644 and 1,142 votes. The Returning Officer declared the respondent No. 1 to be the successful candidate and this declaration was published in the Mysore Gazette on the 11th February, 1952.

facts.text: Returning Officer declared respondent No. 1 successful candidate, published in Mysore Gazette on 11th February 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Returning Officer declared the respondent No. 1 to be the successful candidate and this declaration was published in the Mysore Gazette on the 11th February, 1952. The respondent No. 1 lodged his return of election expenses with the necessary declaration sometime after that and notice of this return was published on the 31st March, 1952.

facts.text: Notice of return of election expenses of respondent No. 1 published on 31st March 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent No. 1 lodged his return of election expenses with the necessary declaration sometime after that and notice of this return was published on the 31st March, 1952. The appellant thereafter filed a petition before the Election Commission, challenging the validity of the election, inter alia, on the grounds that there was violation of the election rules in regard, to certain matters

facts.text: Appellant filed election petition dated 10th April 1952, received by Election Commission on 14th April 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter filed a petition before the Election Commission... This petition, which bears date, 10th of April, 1952, was sent by registered post to the Election Commission and was actually received by the latter on the 14th of April, following.

facts.text: Election Commission referred the matter to Election Tribunal at Shimoga.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Commission referred the matter for determination by the Election Tribunal at Shimoga and it came up for hearing before it on the 25th of October, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant filed application for amendment of petition on 25th October 1952 before Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: and it came up for hearing before it on the 25th of October, 1952. On that date the appellant filed an application for amendment of the petition, heading it as one under Order VI, rule 17, of the Civil Procedure Code, and the only amendment sought for was a modification of the prayer clause by adding a prayer for declaring the entire election to be void.

facts.text: Election Tribunal by majority 2:1 declared election of respondent No. 1 void and appellant duly elected on 15th January 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by a majority of 2 to 1 found all these issues in favour of the petitioner and against the respondent No. 1 and on the strength of their findings on these issues, declared the election of respondent No. 1 to be void and the petitioner to have been duly elected. The judgment of the Tribunal is dated the 15th of January, 1953.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed application under Article 226 before Mysore High Court on 5th February 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On the 5th February, 1953, the respondent No. 1 presented an application before the Mysore High Court under article 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ or direction in the nature of certiorari calling for the records of the proceeding of the Election Tribunal in Election Petition No. I of 195253 and quashing the same including the order pronounced by the Tribunal as mentioned above.

facts.text: Mysore High Court allowed respondent No. 1's petition and issued writ of certiorari on 11th January 1954.

anchor.surface_text: This application was heard by a Division Bench consisting of Medappa C.J. and Balakrishnaiya J. and by their judgment dated the. 11th January, 1954, the learned Judges allowed the petition of respondent No. 1 and directed the issue of a writ of certiorari as prayed for.

facts.text: Petitioner alleged infringement of rules relating to commencement of poll at Booth No. I Ajjampur, polling started half hour late.

anchor.surface_text: Has there been infringement of the rules relating to the time of commencement of poll by reason of the fact that the polling at Booth No. I for Ajjampur fixed at Ajjampur to take place at 8 A.m. did not really commence until about half an hour later as alleged in paragraph 4 of the petition

facts.text: Petitioner alleged respondent No. 1 procured motor bus of Ahmed Jan for conveying voters.

anchor.surface_text: Did the 1st respondent hire and procure a motor bus which was a service bus running between Tarikere and Hiriyur, belonging to one Ahmed Jan, as alleged in paragraph I of the particulars and thereby commit the corrupt practice referred to in it ?

facts.text: Petitioner alleged respondent No. 1 took assistance of Government servants including Paramesshwarappa.

anchor.surface_text: Did the 1st respondent take the assistance of a number of Government servants to further the prospects of his election as alleged in paragraph 2 of the list of particulars ?

facts.text: Petitioner alleged return of election expenses by respondent No. 1 was false and exceeded Rs. 5,000 limit.

anchor.surface_text: Is the return of election expenses lodged by the 1st respondent false in material particulars and has the 1st respondent omitted to include in the return of election expenses, expenses incurred by him in connection with the election which would easily exceed the sanctioned limit of, Rs. 5,000 as per particulars stated in paragraph 7 of the list of particulars

facts.text: Tribunal found issues 1,5,6,11,12,14 in favour of petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by a majority of 2 to 1 found all these issues in favour of the petitioner and against the respondent No. 1 and on the strength of their findings on these issues, declared the election of respondent No. 1 to be void and the petitioner to have been duly elected.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and vacated the writ issued by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the judgment of the High Court cannot be supported and this appeal must be allowed. The writ issued by the High Court will therefore be vacated.

holdings.text: The judgment of the High Court cannot be supported and this appeal must be allowed. The writ issued by the High Court will therefore be vacated.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the judgment of the High Court cannot be supported and this appeal must be allowed. The writ issued by the High Court will therefore be vacated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court misdirected itself on facts and law regarding jurisdiction, excess of jurisdiction, and errors apparent on record; no valid grounds for certiorari existed as Tribunal's findings were supported by evidence and within scope.

holdings.text: There is no question of the Tribunal's entertaining the election petition after the prescribed period in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Tek Chand appearing for the respondent No. 1 plainly confessed his inability to support this view and we must hold therefore that there is no question of the Tribunals entertaining the election petition after the prescribed period in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition despatched by registered post within 14 days excluding publication date under s.81(2)(b) RPA and rule 119; ordinary canons of construction exclude starting date; no extension needed.

holdings.text: The mere fact that the Tribunal granted the petitioner's application for amendment becomes altogether immaterial and has absolutely no bearing on the actual decision in the case.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances the mere fact that the Tribunal granted the petitioners application for amendment becomes altogether immaterial and has absolutely no bearing on the actual decision in the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment only modified prayer clause alternatively; original prayer granted without change to averments; Tribunal's power immaterial as no prejudice.

holdings.text: The finding of the Tribunal arrived at on this point is a finding of fact based on evidence adduced by the parties and it is not in any way outside the pleadings or inconsistent therewith.

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the Tribunal arrived at on this point is a finding of fact based on evidence adduced by the parties and it is not in any way outside the pleadings or inconsistent therewith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pleadings in paras 8-9 alleged corrupt practices by respondent, agents, or with knowledge/connivance; Tribunal findings on procurement, agency, connivance within scope.

holdings.text: It cannot be said that the Tribunal exceeded its jurisdiction in dealing with this matter.

anchor.surface_text: Whether it is right or wrong is another matter and it may be that the view taken by the dissenting member of the Tribunal was the more proper but it cannot be said that the Tribunal exceeded its jurisdiction in dealing with this matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal found 60 voters transported by procured bus, majority likely for respondent wiping 34-vote margin; evidence and math support finding on issue 14.

holdings.text: We cannot say that this is an error apparent on the face of the record which would entitle the High Court to interfere by writ of certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot say that this is an error apparent on the face of the record which would entitle the High Court to interfere by writ of certiorari.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Polling delay finding used under s.100(2)(c) for void election, considering probabilities; not sole basis for declaring petitioner elected.

holdings.text: It is impossible to say that this is an error apparent on the face of the record.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts of accompanying and canvassing by Patel support inference of assistance under s.123(8); not mere canvassing.

holdings.text: On the whole our opinion is that the so-called apparent errors pointed out by the High Court are neither errors of law nor do they appear on the face of the record.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Expenses findings (petrol Rs1250 for 6 cars, hiring/loan equivalent, dinner) based on documentary/oral evidence detailed in Tribunal paras 29d,f; not speculative.

holdings.text: Certiorari will not issue as the cloak of an appeal in disguise... exists to correct error of law when revealed on the face of an order or decision or irregularity or absence of or excess of jurisdiction when shown.

anchor.surface_text: Certiorari may lie and is generally granted when a Court has acted without or in excess of its jurisdiction... it is a patent error which can be corrected by certiorari but not a mere wrong decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restatement of English/Indian precedents: supervisory not appellate jurisdiction; grounds limited to want/excess jurisdiction, natural justice, patent error on face; wide Art 226 not for merits review.
